questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management? (Neet pg 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.correct_answer: D. Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023) 1.Hypokalemia 2.Hypochloremia 3.Metabolic alkalosis 4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Treat at home with oral Amox-clav

options.label: D
options.text: Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.correct_answer: D. Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.
  • • In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage
  • • Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin:
  • • Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.
  • • Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav:
  • • Option C. Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.
  • • Option C. Admit and give IV ceftriaxone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: B

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and recent hospital admission for pneumonia presents with symptoms of confusion, fatigue, and mild nausea. The clinical team suspects syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Which statement about SIADH is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia with low serum osmolality and inappropriately concentrated urine.

options.label: B
options.text: SIADH can be caused by medications, pulmonary diseases, or malignancies, particularly small cell lung cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: Patients with SIADH typically present with hypovolemia and significant edema

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment of SIADH includes fluid restriction and addressing the underlying cause.

questions.correct_answer: C. Patients with SIADH typically present with hypovolemia and significant edema
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • SIADH is a disorder characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leading to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and concentrated urine despite low serum osmolality. It is commonly associated with conditions such as malignancies (especially small cell lung cancer), pulmonary diseases, and medications like antidepressants and antipsychotics. Patients with SIADH are usually euvolemic, without signs of hypovolemia or significant edema, as the retained water is distributed evenly within the body compartments without causing overt fluid overload.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia with low serum osmolality and inappropriately concentrated urine. This statement is correct as it describes the hallmark findings in SIADH, where despite low serum osmolality, the kidneys fail to dilute the urine, leading to continued water retention and worsening hyponatremia.
  • • Option
  • • A. SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia with low serum osmolality and inappropriately concentrated urine.
  • • Option B. SIADH can be caused by medications, pulmonary diseases, or malignancies, particularly small cell lung cancer. This statement is correct. SIADH is commonly linked to various conditions, including small cell lung cancer, certain infections, and drugs that increase ADH release or action.
  • • Option
  • • B. SIADH can be caused by medications, pulmonary diseases, or malignancies, particularly small cell lung cancer.
  • • Option D. Treatment of SIADH includes fluid restriction and addressing the underlying cause. This statement is correct as management of SIADH focuses on restricting free water intake to reduce hyponatremia and treating the underlying condition, such as discontinuing an offending medication or addressing the primary disease process.
  • • Option
  • • D. Treatment of SIADH includes fluid restriction and addressing the underlying cause.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SIADH is characterized by hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and concentrated urine despite normal or elevated ADH levels. It commonly occurs in response to pulmonary diseases, malignancies, or medications. Patients with SIADH are typically euvolemic without significant edema, and management includes fluid restriction and treating the underlying cause. Recognizing the absence of hypovolemia and edema is crucial in differentiating SIADH from other causes of hyponatremia.

questions.text: As an intern in emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum

options.label: B
options.text: Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus

options.label: D
options.text: Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.correct_answer: A. Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum (i.e., N-E-X)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When inserting a nasogastric tube, the correct measurement to estimate the necessary tube length is from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the xiphisternum, ensuring the tube reaches the stomach properly for effective therapeutic or diagnostic use.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10g/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Distal intestinal obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea are common, and one of the significant gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS). This condition should be considered in CF patients presenting with symptoms of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ALS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ALS presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive weakness, and no sensory or autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis

options.label: B
options.text: It is protective against H. pylori infection

options.label: C
options.text: Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

options.label: D
options.text: Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.correct_answer: C. Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.
  • ➤ All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.
  • ➤ high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L)

questions.text: Identify the clinical diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plexiform neurofibromatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plexiform neurofibromatosis should be suspected in patients with extensive, soft, non-tender, and irregularly contoured masses along nerve pathways, particularly in those known to have or suspected of having NF1. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons, though complete removal is often challenging due to the nature of the growth

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

options.label: B
options.text: Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

options.label: C
options.text: Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis

options.label: D
options.text: Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents with weakness and numbness on the right side of his face, along with weakness on the left side of his body. Examination reveals Horner's syndrome (drooping eyelid, constricted pupil, and decreased sweating), nystagmus (rapid involuntary eye movements), vertigo (dizziness), ataxia (loss of coordination), and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). He struggles to maintain his balance. What is the most frequent cause of this presentation? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Blockage of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery

options.label: C
options.text: Blockage of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery

options.label: D
options.text: Blockage of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Blockage of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The combination of symptoms in this patient strongly indicates lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome is most commonly caused by a blockage (occlusion) of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The PICA supplies blood to the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, a region of the brainstem.
  • • Lateral medullary syndrome presents with a characteristic pattern of symptoms. Ipsilateral (same-side) symptoms include facial weakness and numbness, ataxia, Horner's syndrome, and problems with swallowing and speech due to involvement of cranial nerves IX and X. Contralateral (opposite-side) symptoms include loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Blockage of the basilar artery: This would likely cause more severe and widespread brainstem dysfunction, often affecting both sides of the body.
  • • Option B. Blockage of the basilar artery:
  • • Option C. Blockage of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery: This would result in similar symptoms but on the opposite side of the body, with left-sided facial weakness and right-sided body weakness.
  • • Option C. Blockage of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
  • • OPTION D. Blockage of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery: This would primarily affect the lateral pons region of the brainstem, causing a different set of symptoms than those seen in lateral medullary syndrome.
  • • OPTION D. Blockage of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is commonly caused by a blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), resulting in a specific combination of ipsilateral and contralateral neurological deficits. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a patient with hypothyroid symptoms and low TSH that responds to TRH administration, consider hypothalamic dysfunction as a probable cause. This is indicative of secondary hypothyroidism due to a lack of TRH production, affecting the pituitary’s secretion of TSH in the absence of exogenous stimulation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Hypothyroidism/Chap 383

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.correct_answer: C. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.
  • • Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate
  • • metabolic compensation:
  • • Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.
  • • Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation:
  • • Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.
  • • Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the appropriate antidote for fibrinolytic therapy because it inhibits fibrinolysis by preventing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby stabilizing blood clots and reducing bleeding risks.

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.
  • ➤ For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the emergency department with a 4-week history of progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and night sweats. She denies any recent travel or exposure to sick contacts. On physical examination, she is febrile and has bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates and an HRCT scan reveals diffuse ground-glass opacities predominantly in the perihilar regions with small cystic changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP) is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV/AIDS or uncontrolled diabetes. The presence of diffuse ground-glass opacities (GGO) with small cystic changes, particularly in the perihilar regions on HRCT, is highly characteristic of PCP. The clinical presentation of dyspnea, non-productive cough, fever, and weight loss aligns with PCP, which is typically a subacute process. PCP often occurs in patients with weakened immune systems, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes, making this diagnosis the most likely.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Bacterial Pneumonia: Bacterial pneumonia generally presents with lobar or patchy infiltrates on imaging rather than diffuse ground-glass opacities and cystic changes. It is often associated with productive cough, high fever, and pleuritic chest pain, which were not prominently featured in this patient's case.
  • • Option
  • • A) Bacterial Pneumonia:
  • • Option B) Pulmonary Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis may present with systemic symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss, similar to this patient. However, it typically shows upper lobe cavitary lesions or nodular infiltrates on imaging, not the diffuse GGO and cystic changes seen here, making it less likely.
  • • Option
  • • B) Pulmonary Tuberculosis:
  • • Option D) Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): ARDS can cause diffuse ground-glass opacities; however, it is usually associated with an acute onset of symptoms following a known insult, such as sepsis, trauma, or aspiration. This patient’s subacute presentation and lack of a clear precipitating event make ARDS less probable.
  • • Option
  • • D) Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS or uncontrolled diabetes, the presence of diffuse ground-glass opacities with small cystic changes on HRCT is highly indicative of Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP). Recognizing this imaging pattern is crucial for early diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1

options.label: B
options.text: A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

options.label: C
options.text: A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin

options.label: D
options.text: A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH) : Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.
  • • A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH)
  • • B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH) : GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.
  • • B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH)
  • • C. Growth Hormone (GH) : GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.
  • • C. Growth Hormone (GH)
  • • D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1) : IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.
  • • D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1)
  • • The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.
  • ➤ Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VVM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.
  • ➤ Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder leading to a lack of AAT, which protects the lung tissue from elastase. The deficiency causes panacinar emphysema, characterized by uniform enlargement of acini, particularly in the lower lobes of the lung, and presents with chronic respiratory symptoms.

questions.text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.correct_answer: D. Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL) is characterized by the presence of L&H cells, vague nodular formation, and a specific immunophenotypic profile (CD20+, CD45+, EMA+, CD15-, CD30-), which differentiates it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma and other lymphomas.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels

options.label: B
options.text: Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

options.label: C
options.text: Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.correct_answer: B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.
  • • Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C : Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

options.label: A

questions.explanation: Ans. B)

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A drug that is labeled as containing a certain amount of an active ingredient but actually contains a different amount is considered misbranded. Misbranded drugs can lead to ineffective treatment and potential harm due to incorrect dosing.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with confusion, rapid breathing, and severe abdominal pain. Laboratory tests reveal a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with a serum bicarbonate level of 10 mEq/L. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause a high anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) is characterized by a normal anion gap (non-anion gap) metabolic acidosis. It results from the inability of the kidneys to excrete acid or reclaim bicarbonate, but it does not cause a significant accumulation of organic acids like lactate or ketones that would raise the anion gap. Therefore, RTA does not fit the profile of high anion gap acidosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) DKA is associated with high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of ketone bodies (acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate) in the blood. The resulting acidosis is typically accompanied by low bicarbonate levels, making DKA a classic cause of high anion gap acidosis.
  • • Option
  • • A. Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • • Option B. Lactic Acidosis Lactic acidosis is another common cause of high anion gap metabolic acidosis and occurs due to the accumulation of lactic acid, often seen in conditions like sepsis, shock, or tissue hypoxia. The elevated lactate levels contribute to a high anion gap and decreased bicarbonate levels.
  • • Option
  • • B. Lactic Acidosis
  • • Option D. Methanol Poisoning Methanol poisoning leads to high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites, such as formic acid. This condition presents with low bicarbonate levels and is typically associated with symptoms like visual disturbances and CNS depression.
  • • Option
  • • D. Methanol Poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs when acids accumulate in the body, such as in diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and toxin ingestions like methanol. Conditions like renal tubular acidosis, which do not involve significant acid accumulation, present with a normal anion gap despite having low bicarbonate levels. Understanding the difference between high and normal anion gap acidosis is essential in diagnosing and managing these metabolic disturbances.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits her doctor's office complaining of recurrent pain in the right upper abdomen, nausea, and vomiting. She reports that these symptoms occur intermittently and have been happening for the past few months. Her doctor orders some tests, including an abdominal ultrasound, blood work, and a HIDA scan. After reviewing the results, the doctor diagnoses her with biliary dyskinesia. To determine the most effective treatment plan, the doctor considers various factors, including the patient's medical history, age, and overall health status. Which diagnostic test will be the least helpful in confirming the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) USG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key point to remember is that USG, despite its utility in detecting structural anomalies in the biliary tract, is not effective in diagnosing functional disorders like biliary dyskinesia. Functional tests like the HIDA scan or ERCP with manometry are necessary for a definitive diagnosis of functional biliary disorders.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

questions.text: A woman presents with lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size, and appear pale. The histopathological image shows multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. The diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that presents with dome-shaped papules containing Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are diagnostic of this condition.
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)

questions.explanation: Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? ( INICET May 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same

options.label: B
options.text: Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles

options.label: C
options.text: Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same

questions.correct_answer: B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? ( INICET Nov 2021)

Ans. D) PTSD

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the fertility clinic with a two-year history of unsuccessful attempts to conceive with his partner. He reports a long-standing history of recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis, and occasional episodes of productive cough. On further questioning, he also mentions episodes of nasal congestion and a previous diagnosis of situs inversus, where his heart is located on the right side of his chest. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his infertility?

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormal sperm motility due to ciliary dysfunction

questions.correct_answer: C. Abnormal sperm motility due to ciliary dysfunction
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kartagener's syndrome, a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia, is characterized by defective cilia due to mutations affecting the dynein arms that are essential for ciliary movement. This dysfunction leads to ineffective clearing of mucus from the respiratory tract, resulting in recurrent respiratory infections, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus. In males, the ciliary dysfunction extends to the sperm flagella, leading to abnormal sperm motility, which is a primary cause of infertility in these patients despite normal sperm count. The immotile sperm cannot effectively reach and fertilize the ovum, causing infertility.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypogonadism: Hypogonadism involves inadequate production of testosterone or sperm and is characterized by low sperm count or absent sperm production, often accompanied by decreased libido and erectile dysfunction. This is not a feature of Kartagener's syndrome, which presents with normal spermatogenesis but impaired motility.
  • • Option
  • • A. Hypogonadism:
  • • Option B. Blockage of the vas deferens: Blockage of the vas deferens leads to obstructive azoospermia, where sperm cannot be transported out of the testicles. This is a common feature of cystic fibrosis rather than Kartagener’s syndrome and does not account for the normal sperm count with poor motility seen here.
  • • Option
  • • B. Blockage of the vas deferens:
  • • Option D. Genetic mutation affecting spermatogenesis: While genetic mutations can affect spermatogenesis directly, causing abnormal or decreased sperm production, this does not fit the scenario of Kartagener's syndrome, where sperm production is normal but motility is impaired due to dysfunctional ciliary movement.
  • • Option
  • • D. Genetic mutation affecting spermatogenesis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener's syndrome, part of primary ciliary dyskinesia, leads to infertility primarily due to abnormal sperm motility caused by defective ciliary and flagellar movement. Patients commonly present with respiratory symptoms and situs inversus due to similar ciliary dysfunction in respiratory epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which cells are not present in the layer marked as D? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)

Ans. D) Langerhans cells

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? ( NICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exosome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.correct_answer: A. Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psychotic depression In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression ), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.
  • ➤ psychotic depression
  • ➤ mood congruent

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: Hypereosinophilic syndrome is a condition characterized by an abnormally high count of eosinophils in the blood for a minimum of 6 months, without any apparent underlying cause, and with involvement of the heart, nervous system, or bone marrow. What is the minimum eosinophil count required for this diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) is defined by a persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in the blood for at least six months. The diagnostic criteria for HES stipulate that the eosinophil count should be equal to or greater than 1500 cells per cubic millimeter (mm³) of blood.
  • • This elevated eosinophil count can cause damage to various organs, leading to a range of symptoms and complications. These can include heart problems (cardiomyopathy), digestive issues (gastroenteritis), skin abnormalities, sinus inflammation, lung inflammation, nerve damage, and blood vessel inflammation. Some individuals may also experience blood clots, enlargement of the liver and spleen, and other blood cell abnormalities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. >500/mm³ : This eosinophil count, while elevated, is not high enough to meet the diagnostic threshold for HES.
  • • Option A. >500/mm³
  • • Option B. >1000/mm³ : Similar to option a, this count is elevated but falls below the required level for diagnosing HES.
  • • Option B. >1000/mm³
  • • Option D. >2000/mm³ : While this indicates a significant increase in eosinophils, the definitive criterion for HES is an eosinophil count of 1500/mm³ or higher.
  • • Option D. >2000/mm³

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of hypereosinophilic syndrome hinges on the presence of a persistently elevated eosinophil count of 1500/mm³ or more for a minimum of 6 months, along with signs of organ damage attributable to eosinophils, and the absence of an identifiable cause for the increased eosinophil levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Agranulocytosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine, requiring regular monitoring of white blood cell counts to ensure early detection and prevention of serious infections.

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:
  • • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes. Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.
  • • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • • Hyperpigmentation:
  • • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.
  • • Vision deficits:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sheehan syndrome : Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.
  • • Option B. Sheehan syndrome
  • • Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.
  • • Option C. Conn's syndrome:
  • • Option D. Addison's disease: Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.
  • • Option D. Addison's disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Left atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text: A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022) LES is open and UES is closed. Strong contractions in the stomach. Inspiration against a closed glottis. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter. LES opens and UES opens. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine. LES: Lower esophageal sphincter UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sequence of events in act of vomiting:
  • ➤ Sequence of events in act of vomiting:
  • ➤ Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing Closure of glottis Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone Elevation of soft palate Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.
  • ➤ Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  • ➤ Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  • ➤ Closure of glottis
  • ➤ Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  • ➤ Elevation of soft palate
  • ➤ Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  • ➤ Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  • ➤ Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  • ➤ Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gate control theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain primarily through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following statement is True regarding trematodes? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

options.label: C
options.text: Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water

options.label: D
options.text: Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.correct_answer: A. Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fasciola hepatica is found in the intrahepatic biliary radicles of its definitive host. It is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae on aquatic vegetation, and its treatment of choice is triclabendazole. Schistosomes, unlike other trematodes, are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes.

questions.text: In a fetal monitoring, which of the following factors primarily contributes to an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration during labor and delivery, signifying fetal well-being? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carotid body chemoreceptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels and contributing to fetal heart rate acceleration during labor, indicating fetal well-being.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement 2 years ago presents to the emergency department with fever, fatigue, and a new heart murmur. He reports intermittent chills and night sweats for the past 3 weeks. Physical examination reveals splinter hemorrhages on his fingernails and a 2/6 diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Blood cultures are positive, and an echocardiogram shows a vegetation on the prosthetic aortic valve. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Streptococcus viridans is the most common cause of late-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE), which occurs more than 12 months after valve replacement. This organism is often implicated because it commonly colonizes the oral cavity and can enter the bloodstream during dental procedures or other transient bacteremias, leading to infection of the prosthetic valve. Unlike early PVE, late PVE resembles native valve endocarditis and frequently involves viridans group streptococci.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Staphylococcus epidermidis Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS), is the leading cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis, typically occurring within the first 2 months post-surgery. Its association with early infection is due to contamination during surgery, and it is less likely to cause late-onset PVE.
  • • Option
  • • A. Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus can cause both early and late prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially in patients with intravenous drug use or healthcare-associated exposures. However, it is more frequently associated with early PVE or acute, aggressive presentations rather than the subacute symptoms seen in this case.
  • • Option
  • • C. Staphylococcus aureus
  • • Option D. Enterococcus faecalis Enterococcus faecalis can cause prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially in patients with a history of gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures. However, it is less commonly involved than Streptococcus viridans in late PVE and is more often seen in early or healthcare-associated infections.
  • • Option
  • • D. Enterococcus faecalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prosthetic valve endocarditis occurring more than 12 months after valve replacement is most commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans, reflecting its similarity to native valve endocarditis. Recognizing the timeline and the typical pathogens associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • ➤ Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.
